item.title: Beogram 4000: Choppily Rotating AC Platter Motor - Repair of Wien-Bridge Oscillator Circuit
item.description:
This Beogram 4000 restoration project presented a recurring issue: a malfunctioning oscillator circuit responsible for powering the AC platter motor. This was unusual, as previous 4002 and 4000 models hadn’t shown this problem. Although the light bulbs managing the circuit’s Automatic Gain Control (AGC) weren’t visually illuminated during motor operation, suggesting a longer lifespan compared to indicator bulbs, this unit proved otherwise. It’s likely that factors like mechanical vibrations, particularly during transport, could have damaged the bulbs...

item.title: Beomaster 8000: Microcomputer Board Reworked
item.description:
I worked on the Beomaster 8000 microcomputer board today. This Beomaster is an earlier model and uses a first-generation microcomputer board, unlike later models with directly replaceable, yet distinct, boards. I’ll show an example of a later model board at the end. One issue with the first-generation boards is the metal enclosure surrounding the processor ICs. While necessary for shielding, it makes accessing components difficult. B&O used soldered metal tabs to connect the upper and lower sections, but these tabs are soldered to the board’s ground plane, requiring significant heat for removal...
